* [http://www.armenian-patriarchate.org/ Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem] }}

The 'Armenian Apostolic Church' (}}) is the world's oldest [[State
religion|national church]], It was the first nation to adopt Christianity as
its official religion. The Journal of Ecclesiastical History â Page 268 by
Cambridge University Press, Gale Group, C.W. Dugmore http://www.cnewa.org/ecc-bodypg-
us.aspx?eccpageID=5 The Armenian Massacres, 1894â1896: 1894â1896 :
U.S. media testimony â Page 131 by A. Dzh. (Arman Dzhonovich)
Kirakosian http://orientalorthodox.org/armenian.htm is part of
[[Oriental Orthodoxy]] and is one of the most ancient [[Christianity|Christian]]
communities. The Antiquities of the Christian Church â Page 466 by Johann
Christian Wilhelm Augusti, Georg Friedrich Heinrich Rheinwald, Carl Christian
Friedrich Siegel [[Armenia]] was the first country to adopt Christianity
as its official religion in AD 301, in establishing this church. {{cite
book|first=RenÃ©|last=Grousset|title=Histoire de
l'ArmÃ©nie|publisher=Payot|year=1947|edition=1984|page=122}}. Estimated dates
vary from 284 to 314. GarsoÃ¯an (op.cit.'' p.82), following the research of
Ananian, favours the latter. The Armenian Apostolic Orthodox Church claims
to trace its origins to the missions of Apostles Bartholomew and Thaddeus in the
1st century and is an early center of Christianity.

It is sometimes referred to as the 'Gregorian Church' but this name is not
preferred by the church itself, as it views the Apostles Bartholomew and
Thaddeus as its founders, and St. Gregory the Illuminator as merely the first
official governor of the church.
